reasoning: The critique targets a load-bearing numerical move in the position: fixing α=0.5 to translate ρ estimates into “max speed” ceilings, then using the resulting low ceilings to argue most negative-ρ estimates are implausible. In CES with ρ<0, the ceiling as L→∞ is Y_max = (α K^ρ)^{1/ρ} = α^{1/ρ}K, so it is indeed highly sensitive to α; raising α toward 1 drives the ceiling toward ~K (i.e., near-1×), undercutting the position’s argument that negative-ρ estimates imply absurdly low ceilings. That said, the position offers many independent objections to importing economy-wide ρ into AI R&D (experiments becoming more compute-efficient, extrapolation issues, alternative routes, etc.), so even fully accepting the α point weakens a major intuition pump but does not by itself collapse the overall conclusion. The critique is clear, focused, and mostly correct; its main limitation is not quantifying plausible α for AI R&D or engaging the other non-α counterarguments, reducing total refutational impact.
title: Arbitrary alpha parameter makes ceiling calculations unreliable
